sub_topic: Schwarz reflection principle and its applications
message_1:
Find the analytic function $f(z)$ given that it satisfies the following conditions:
1. $f(z)$ is analytic in $\mathbb{C}^-$, where $\mathbb{C}^-$ is the lower half of the complex plane.
2. $f(z)$ converges to 1 as $z$ approaches infinity in $\mathbb{C}^-$.
3. $f(z)$ is real-valued on the real axis.
4. For $z$ in the real axis $-\infty<z<0$, $f(z) = e^{2z}$.
Use the Schwarz reflection principle to extend $f(z)$ into the upper half plane $\mathbb{C}^+$.
message_2:
To use the Schwarz reflection principle, we first need to find an analytic function $g(z)$ that is the reflection of $f(z)$ across the real axis. Since $f(z)$ is real-valued on the real axis and $f(z) = e^{2z}$ for $-\infty < z < 0$, we can define the reflection $g(z)$ as the complex conjugate of $f(z)$ for $z$ in the upper half-plane:

$$g(z) = \overline{f(\bar{z})}$$

Now, we want to find an analytic function that agrees with $f(z)$ in the lower half-plane and with $g(z)$ in the upper half-plane. We can define this function as:

$$h(z) = \begin{cases}
f(z), & \text{if } \Im(z) \leq 0 \\
g(z), & \text{if } \Im(z) > 0
\end{cases}$$

Since $f(z)$ and $g(z)$ are both analytic in their respective domains and agree on the real axis, $h(z)$ is analytic in the whole complex plane. Moreover, $h(z)$ converges to 1 as $z$ approaches infinity in both the lower and upper half-planes, since $f(z)$ and $g(z)$ do.

Now, we need to find an explicit expression for $h(z)$. We know that $f(z) = e^{2z}$ for $-\infty < z < 0$. To find the expression for $g(z)$, we can use the definition $g(z) = \overline{f(\bar{z})}$:

$$g(z) = \overline{f(\bar{z})} = \overline{e^{2\bar{z}}} = e^{2\overline{z}}$$

So, we can write $h(z)$ as:

$$h(z) = \begin{cases}
e^{2z}, & \text{if } \Im(z) \leq 0 \\
e^{2\overline{z}}, & \text{if } \Im(z) > 0
\end{cases}$$

This is the analytic function that satisfies the given conditions and extends $f(z)$ into the upper half-plane using the Schwarz reflection principle.
